By ALAN HIRSCH
In what may result in a
significant improvement in the
University housing situation,

Possibility of purchasing an

Pilkington pane protection pondered
By ALAN HIRSCH
The University is continuing to
examine the shatttering of some
of the glass panes in the Glass
Pavilion of the Union last year as
well as possible solutions to such
future occurrences.
School officials, after meeting
with the Pavilion's Architect and
Contractor, and the
manufacturer of the glass, have
asked Dr. Edwin Fitzgerald,
Mechanics and Material Sciences,
to investigate some possible
causes for the shattering of the
glass.
Four of the Pavilions panes
were destroyed last year in three
separate incidents. The
University had been informed
prior to construction of the
Union by its architect Donald
Sickler that breakage would not
be a problem and that
rock-throwing in particular
would not pose a threat to the
glass panes, which cost $600
apiece.
In at least two of the
incidents, rock-throwing was
probably the primary cause of
the shattering of the glass,
officials here believe.
Bill Campbell, Director of
Plant Operations, said that all
possible explanations are being
examined and that legal action
against one of the companies
involved in the design and

construction of the building is
still a possibility, though no
action will be taken until further
research is conducted.
Fitzgerald is now in the.
process of investigating the glass'
"Dynamic Mechanical
Properties," analyzing the effect

of different kinds of vibrations
on the glass.
He suggested that some of the
glass shatterings may have been
the result of vibrations from
motors in the building, wind
gusts, or certain sounds.
Also, the nature of the glass

could be such that in could
withstand large stress needed to
support the building, but be
shattered by a small
vibration—possibly wind or
sound waves—applied very
suddenly. Fitzgerald said.

Despite the new law rents will continue skyward
Despite the Baltimore City
Council's recent passage of a
detailed and explicit rent control
ordinance, Hopkins students
renting off-campus domiciles can
expect the usual trouble this year
in comb atting excessive rent
hikes.
The bill, passed as City
Ordinance 949, protects
Baltimore residents from rent
increases greater than 6 percent
until July 1, 1976, at which time
the City Council is expected to
review the effect of inflation on
the overhead costs of city
landlords and arrive at a new
ceiling for rent hikes.
However, the city's inability to
effectively enforce the ordinance
has enabled landlords to take
advantage of certain
contingencies in the bill and levy
unlawful rent hikes. Students and
elderly residents of the
Homewood area have recently
been feeling the effects of this
situation.
Area landlords have relied on
section C of the ordinance, a
disclaimer which entitles them to
add to the permissible 6 percent
hike "the proportionate share of
the amount of any increases in
costs to the landlord for the
premises..,resulting from
increases in real estate taxes,
water and sewage charges, utility
rates, and heating fuel charges."
The disclaimer requires, though,
that landlords demonstrate in
writing the basis for any
proportionate increase beyond 6

per cent.
But many tenants have found
it very difficult to contest
unlawful rent hikes for a variety
of reasons. First of all, the State
Attorney General's office is no
longer charged with enforcing
rent control legislation, leaving
Baltimore City agencies to bear
the full brunt of enforcement.
Since state-wide rent control
was cancelled by the state
legislature last year, rent control
laws have been passed only on a
city-wide basis in Maryland.
Attorney General Francis Burch
complained publicly last year of
his office's inability to handle the
massive number of rent control
appeals. The city agencies do not
appear up to the task of full
enforcement either.
Tenants have sought the help
of Legal Aid branches in

Jake Hall

Baltimore only to find them
already glutted with similar rent
control appeals and unable to
handle any new ones until the
present backlog has dissipated.
Since most students and other
Charles Village tenants cannot
afford to hire private counsel,
many have no choice but to live
with the illegal rent increases.
Belva Scott, Hopkins'
coordinator of Outside Housing,
said yesterday that Hopkins
students have requested help
from her office in dealing with
excessive increases. Many have
been refused help by Legal Aid
and cannot afford a private

attorney, she said.
"My advice has been to either
live with the rent increase or
move to a different apartment,"
she explained. "The cost of
hiring an attorney would be
greater than the rent increase
itself."
Unfortunately for Hopkins
students, the University is not in
a good position to help them in
combatting illegal increases. The
University counsels are not
empowered to appeal such a case
in court, and the administration
appears unwilling to establish a
precedent of standing behind
students in such affairs.

Witholding rent is now legal
Beginning this July, residents
of rented apartments and houses
could legally withold rent when
landlords have ignored requested
repairs of hazardous conditions.
The new rules, which became
law April 22, state that tenants
who have given notice by
certified mail of hazardous
conditions that have not been
corrected within 30 days can
stop the rent payments or put
them into an escrow account.
Conditions such as lack of
heat, light, electricity, of hot or
cold water or adequate sewage
are covered by the law.
Fire hazards, infestation of
rodents in two or more dwelling
units, and the existence of
lead-bearing paint on walls within
the building are also considered a
basis for withholding rent.
Minor defects or housing code
violations of a non-dangerous
nature which are not corrected
are not considered a cause for
stopping rent payments.
These minor defects include
such problems as a lack of fresh
paint, disfigured rugs, paneling or
decorative amenities.
Small cracks on the walls,
floors and ceilings, the absence of
tile on floors which are otherwise
sound and the absence of air
conditioning also do not
constitute hazardous conditions.
One technical advisor of the
Home Builders Association of
Maryland said the law contained
a "rebuttal presumption" which
said that these minor defects
would not affect landlords or the

tenant contract.

last recognized the significance of housing as a student
priority, we would like to suggest that the administration
employ considerable caution as it investigates methods of
increasing Hopkins' housing resources.
While it is true that the current shortage of on-campus
housing for undergraduates may deter some prospective
students from attending Hopkins, we feel that the
construction or purchase of new housing space—a risky
enough endeavor under any circumstances—is a dangerous
proposition in the present strapped economy. And to be sure
there is no shortage of other less risky and more important
areas in which money could be invested.
Though there are some students who feel more strongly
about the priority of housing, we do not consider it a
pre-eminent concern. We encourage the University to explore
all possible methods of improving the lot of the student
housing-wise, but feel that the construction of on-campus
housing entails enormous risks—student enrollments and
preferences cannot be predicted accurately enough to justify
such a long-term undertaking. In addition, the shortage of
on-campus living space has the curious benefit of imposing on
students the valuable education that accompanies living in
the city on one's own.
With the Library and other academic and administrative
departments sorely in need of funds, the huge investment
which could result from the administration's investigation of
housing resources would be an ill-advised venture, especially
since there are other methods of ameliorating the Hopkins
housing dilemma.

Before the University proceeds and invests in additional
Housing, it would be wise to first consider utilizing privately
owned housing in the Homewood area to its fullest extent.

off-campus housing is clearly a commendable step in that
direction.

to them. But, if the University, for example, would place its

difficulty with area landlords, or even better, if it would

intimidated by their landlords, student satisfaction with

same time, the University would be fulfilling its obligation to
combat discriminatory housing practices—one of the
justifications for .the, University's acquisition of additional
housing. If students are denied good housing because they are
women, black, or simply students, the reaction should not be
to return to the cloister of the University, but to work, and if
necessary, fight for the right to live in the community.

somewhat unpredictable, and social change as desirable as it
ever was, such a solution makes good sense. Perhaps the
individual cannot change leasing practices in the Homewood
area, but it seems likely that the University as agents for
thousands could.

Despite the new law rents will continue skyward
Despite the Baltimore City
Council's recent passage of a
detailed and explicit rent control
ordinance, Hopkins students
renting off-campus domiciles can
expect the usual trouble this year
in comb atting excessive rent
hikes.
The bill, passed as City
Ordinance 949, protects
Baltimore residents from rent
increases greater than 6 percent
until July 1, 1976, at which time
the City Council is expected to
review the effect of inflation on
the overhead costs of city
landlords and arrive at a new
ceiling for rent hikes.
However, the city's inability to
effectively enforce the ordinance
has enabled landlords to take
advantage of certain
contingencies in the bill and levy
unlawful rent hikes. Students and
elderly residents of the
Homewood area have recently
been feeling the effects of this
situation.
Area landlords have relied on
section C of the ordinance, a
disclaimer which entitles them to
add to the permissible 6 percent
hike "the proportionate share of
the amount of any increases in
costs to the landlord for the
premises..,resulting from
increases in real estate taxes,
water and sewage charges, utility
rates, and heating fuel charges."
The disclaimer requires, though,
that landlords demonstrate in
writing the basis for any
proportionate increase beyond 6

per cent.
But many tenants have found
it very difficult to contest
unlawful rent hikes for a variety
of reasons. First of all, the State
Attorney General's office is no
longer charged with enforcing
rent control legislation, leaving
Baltimore City agencies to bear
the full brunt of enforcement.
Since state-wide rent control
was cancelled by the state
legislature last year, rent control
laws have been passed only on a
city-wide basis in Maryland.
Attorney General Francis Burch
complained publicly last year of
his office's inability to handle the
massive number of rent control
appeals. The city agencies do not
appear up to the task of full
enforcement either.
Tenants have sought the help
of Legal Aid branches in

Jake Hall

Baltimore only to find them
already glutted with similar rent
control appeals and unable to
handle any new ones until the
present backlog has dissipated.
Since most students and other
Charles Village tenants cannot
afford to hire private counsel,
many have no choice but to live
with the illegal rent increases.
Belva Scott, Hopkins'
coordinator of Outside Housing,
said yesterday that Hopkins
students have requested help
from her office in dealing with
excessive increases. Many have
been refused help by Legal Aid
and cannot afford a private

attorney, she said.
"My advice has been to either
live with the rent increase or
move to a different apartment,"
she explained. "The cost of
hiring an attorney would be
greater than the rent increase
itself."
Unfortunately for Hopkins
students, the University is not in
a good position to help them in
combatting illegal increases. The
University counsels are not
empowered to appeal such a case
in court, and the administration
appears unwilling to establish a
precedent of standing behind
students in such affairs.

Witholding rent is now legal
Beginning this July, residents
of rented apartments and houses
could legally withold rent when
landlords have ignored requested
repairs of hazardous conditions.
The new rules, which became
law April 22, state that tenants
who have given notice by
certified mail of hazardous
conditions that have not been
corrected within 30 days can
stop the rent payments or put
them into an escrow account.
Conditions such as lack of
heat, light, electricity, of hot or
cold water or adequate sewage
are covered by the law.
Fire hazards, infestation of
rodents in two or more dwelling
units, and the existence of
lead-bearing paint on walls within
the building are also considered a
basis for withholding rent.
Minor defects or housing code
violations of a non-dangerous
nature which are not corrected
are not considered a cause for
stopping rent payments.
These minor defects include
such problems as a lack of fresh
paint, disfigured rugs, paneling or
decorative amenities.
Small cracks on the walls,
floors and ceilings, the absence of
tile on floors which are otherwise
sound and the absence of air
conditioning also do not
constitute hazardous conditions.
One technical advisor of the
Home Builders Association of
Maryland said the law contained
a "rebuttal presumption" which
said that these minor defects
would not affect landlords or the

tenant contract.

While we are glad to see that University officials have at
last recognized the significance of housing as a student
priority, we would like to suggest that the administration
employ considerable caution as it investigates methods of
increasing Hopkins' housing resources.
While it is true that the current shortage of on-campus
housing for undergraduates may deter some prospective
students from attending Hopkins, we feel that the
construction or purchase of new housing space—a risky
enough endeavor under any circumstances—is a dangerous
proposition in the present strapped economy. And to be sure
there is no shortage of other less risky and more important
areas in which money could be invested.
Though there are some students who feel more strongly
about the priority of housing, we do not consider it a
pre-eminent concern. We encourage the University to explore
all possible methods of improving the lot of the student
housing-wise, but feel that the construction of on-campus
housing entails enormous risks—student enrollments and
preferences cannot be predicted accurately enough to justify
such a long-term undertaking. In addition, the shortage of
on-campus living space has the curious benefit of imposing on
students the valuable education that accompanies living in
the city on one's own.
With the Library and other academic and administrative
departments sorely in need of funds, the huge investment
which could result from the administration's investigation of
housing resources would be an ill-advised venture, especially
since there are other methods of ameliorating the Hopkins
housing dilemma.

Before the University proceeds and invests in additional
Housing, it would be wise to first consider utilizing privately
owned housing in the Homewood area to its fullest extent.
The appointment of Belva Scott as Coordinator of
off-campus housing is clearly a commendable step in that
direction.
However, as Scott stated yesterday, there is little that the
housing office can do in dealing with landlords other than talk
to them. But, if the University, for example, would place its
considerable influence behind those students who are having
difficulty with area landlords, or even better, if it would
provide a certain amount of legal assistance for students being
intimidated by their landlords, student satisfaction with
community housing will undoubtedly improve. And at the
same time, the University would be fulfilling its obligation to
combat discriminatory housing practices—one of the
justifications for .the, University's acquisition of additional
housing. If students are denied good housing because they are
women, black, or simply students, the reaction should not be
to return to the cloister of the University, but to work, and if
necessary, fight for the right to live in the community.
At a time when money is tight, future enrollments
somewhat unpredictable, and social change as desirable as it
ever was, such a solution makes good sense. Perhaps the
individual cannot change leasing practices in the Homewood
area, but it seems likely that the University as agents for
thousands could.

By KEN SOKOLOW
In the summer of 1860, the
upstart Republican party held its
national convention in Chicago
and nominated Abraham Lincoln
for President—above the protests
of the city fathers of Baltimore.
who had agitated for the
convention to be held here in
Mobtown. The leaders of the
party pointed out to the mayor
and city council of Baltimore
that it would not be appropriate
for the party opposing the
expansion of slavery—and
composed of ex-Northern Whigs,
Free Soilers, and even some
Abolitionists—to hold its
conclave in a city so one-sidedly
pro-slavery, pro-South, and
pro-secession as Baltimore. The
city fathers could not follow this
line of reasoning; they had no
regard for principles and wanted
the convention in Baltimore for
the money it would bring in.
"Wait til '64 and submit your
proposal again," party leader
William Henry Seward told them.
But anti-Republican sentiments
continued to roll and rankle in
the Monumental City. When
Lincoln passed through town on
his way to inauguration in
Washington, he narrowly escaped
assassination.
Getting Our Licks In
The first blood of the Civil
War was not shed at Bull Run,
but on Pratt Street in Baltimore.
Shortly after the fiasco at Ft.
Sumter, President Lincoln
ordered Federal troops sent to
Washington to protect the capital
against attack from the seceded
Virginia and the (as it was then
thought) soon -to -secede
Maryland. The First
Massachusetts Regiment, on its
way to Washington, had to
change trains in Baltimore.
Marching down Pratt Street
toward the President Street
Station, the New Englanders
were attacked by a
stone-throwing, club-carrying
mob of pro-Southern hooligans
who had met at the Shot Tower,
a popular local bar, to plan their
riot. There were fatalities on
both sides.

Soon after this incident, the
state of Maryland found itself
under Northern military
occupation. The governor of
Maryland, a moderate named

that he did not want his state to

become an abattoir; he prevented
the state from seceding from the
Union. This did not satisfy
President Lincoln, who,

corpus, had the mayor, chief of

Baltimore seized and thrown into
the dungeons of Ft. McHenry

As a result of the need for the
